content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Act of October 21, 1970, regarding the Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore is amended to allow owners of improved property to extend their right of use and occupancy. Owners must be notified of this right and can choose to extend it within 180 days of receiving the notice. The Act of October 21, 1970, allows owners of improved property to extend their right of use and occupancy beyond the termination date. The extension can last until the date of death of the owner on January 1, 1996, or 25 years after the election. If the owner dies before the 25-year mark, the right can only be transferred to immediate family members. The Act of October 21, 1970 allows property owners to extend their right of use and occupancy. The extension is subject to certain conditions, including annual payments and assuming responsibilities for maintenance. The Act of October 21, 1970 allows property owners to extend their right of use and occupancy by making annual payments and assuming responsibilities for maintenance, repair, and replacement of improvements on the property. Additionally, they must indemnify the United States for any liability related to the property and make pro rata payments to local governments for services provided to residents within the lakeshore boundaries. The Act of October 21, 1970 allows property owners to extend their right of use by making annual payments based on the property's value. These payments are retained by the Secretary for maintenance and administration of the national lakeshore. The Act of October 21, 1970 allows property owners to extend their right of use by making annual payments based on the property's value. Following an extension, the Secretary may lease the property to family members for a definite or indefinite term. The lease can be terminated if the Secretary decides to remove structures and restore the property for public access. The lease payments will be retained by the Secretary for maintenance. Section 10(c) of the Act is amended to replace "many" with "may", and Section 11(a)(2) is amended to replace "section 10 (b) or (d)" with "section 10".
